objects.name: Attack Flow
objects.description: Extends STIX 2.1 with features to create Attack Flows.

external_references.description: Source code repository for Attack Flow

objects.name: MSP Supply-Chain - Azure Virtual Desktop (AVD) cached-session compromise (Australia, early 2024)
objects.description: This attack describes an opportunistic supply-chain intrusion targeting a managed service provider (MSP) relationship that administered an Azure Virtual Desktop (AVD) tenant for a healthcare organisation in Australia. In the observed case, an adversary leveraged a compromised personal/contractor device that contained recoverable AVD session artifacts (cached tokens / SSO artifacts). By extracting and reusing these cached artifacts the actor established authenticated AVD sessions without triggering normal interactive authentication flows, effectively bypassing primary credential prompts and multifactor authentication (MFA). Once inside the tenant, the actor performed light discovery, attempted credential harvesting and lateral pivots to internal resources, and was disrupted when the MSP and victim rapidly terminated sessions and forced credential resets. This case highlights the elevated risk posed by unmanaged endpoints in MSP supply chains and the specific danger of persistent cached session artifacts.

external_references.source_name: ASD / ACSC advisory example (APT behaviour & VDI/VDI-like artefacts discussion).
Western Australia SOC guidance (incident detection/response / local context).
Microsoft â€” Revoke user access in Microsoft Entra ID (how to invalidate refresh tokens / force sign-out).

objects.name: Opportunistic Access Broker / Financially-motivated Criminal Group
objects.description: The likely actor in this supply-chain/AVD cached-session case is an opportunistic, financially-motivated criminal group or access broker. They operate by discovering exposed vendor relationships (MSPs), identifying weakly-managed endpoints (personal/contractor devices), harvesting session artifacts or credentials, and either monetising access (selling it on access markets) or exploiting it directly (credential harvesting, lateral movement, exfiltration, ransomware).
secondary_motivations: monetisation via resale to ransomware gangs or fraud groups.

objects.name: RECON-01A - Vendor-Client Mapping (MSP targeting)
objects.description: Map MSPs and their client rosters (public case studies, trade directories, LinkedIn company pages) and enumerate administrative portals and management endpoints (e.g., MSP consoles, tenant admin URLs). They identify which MSPs manage clients in sensitive sectors (health, logistics) to prioritise targets.

objects.name: RECON-01B - OSINT on Users & Contractors
objects.description: Gather names, roles, and contact details of MSP staff and contractor accounts that have remote access privileges. Prioritize accounts likely to use personal devices or remote access with persistent sessions (consultants, contractors, admins). Tools include LinkedIn scraping, corporate staff pages, public contractor listings, and breach dump searches.

objects.name: RECON-01C - Breach Correlation / Credential Leak Matching
objects.description: Cross-reference enumerated user emails with public breach dumps and paste sites to find likely reused credentials. Where found, the actor ranks targets by reuse risk and ease of access. This can inform whether to attempt immediate token harvest or to try credential stuffing.

objects.name: RECON-TOOLING (explain tooling) - as extra contextual node
objects.description:
Common scanning & enrichment tools:

Internet scanning: masscan, nmap (fast port discovery)

Internet asset search: Shodan, ZoomEye (fingerprint appliances, broker endpoints)

OSINT: custom Python/BeautifulSoup scrapers, LinkedIn queries, Google dorking

Small automation: credential stuffing frameworks, Selenium for phishing credential capture in tests (research only)
MSP-PRECONDITION-CACHEDSESSION
objects.pattern: Are recoverable AVD cached session artifacts (tokens, saved SSO cookies, cached session files) present on the personal / contractor device?
objects.pattern_version:
TRUE (CACHED PRESENT): actor can perform low-noise session reuse = MSP-EXPLOIT-USE-CACHED-SESS.

FALSE (NO CACHED ARTIFACTS): actor must use a noisier initial access method.

objects.name: MSP-EXPLOIT-USE-CACHED-SESS
objects.description: Attacker extracts cached AVD session tokens or SSO artifacts (browser/system cache, encrypted token stores, saved RDP connection files) from the personal device and imports or replays them to establish authenticated AVD sessions. Because the token represents an already-validated authentication context, MFA and normal interactive flows are bypassed.

objects.name: MSP-SESSION-ACCESS
objects.description: Authenticated session(s) are visible in AVD or tenant logs. The attacker enumerates the environment, lists available desktops and mounted drives, and identifies services or management functions reachable from the session. Because authentication was not interactive, defenders may need to correlate session logs with Azure AD sign-in logs to detect anomalies.

objects.name: MSP-POST-ACCESS-RECON (Discovery)
objects.description: Enumerate internal hosts, file shares, privileged accounts, and management consoles accessible via the AVD session. Use built-in tools, PowerShell, or light network scanning. Look for credentials, service accounts, or misconfigurations enabling privilege escalation.

objects.name: MSP-LONG-TERM-STEALTH (persistence)
objects.description: Actor chooses to remain stealthy, create low-noise persistence (stable service account, scheduled tasks, living-off-the-land tooling). Use this when monetisation is intended later or to avoid immediate detection. Dwell may extend into weeks/months if undetected.

objects.name: MSP-CRED-HARVEST
objects.description: If reachable, attacker harvests credentials (LSASS memory dumps, cached credential stores, service account files) and obtains tokens/tickets enabling lateral movement or persistence. Harvested credentials are staged on a local attacker file or uploaded to a staging server.

objects.name: Credentials / Tokens
objects.description: credentials/tokens harvested

objects.name: MSP-LATERAL-MOVEMENT
objects.description: Using harvested credentials or existing sessions, the actor pivots to internal systems (file servers, EHR, database servers). Methods include RDP hops, SMB access, PsExec, or WinRM. Observe for new admin accounts, mass file reads, or roaming RDP connections. Rapid MSP/tenant response can break pivot attempts.

objects.name: MSP-EXFILTRATION (possible)
objects.description: Sensitive data (patient records, manifests) may be staged and exfiltrated to attacker-controlled cloud storage or VPS. Exfil may be chunked over HTTPS, or uploaded to public cloud storage using stolen service account keys. The ACSC case reported no confirmed patient data loss, but modelling the exfil path is critical.

objects.name: MSP-TOKEN-SALE / Access resale (monetisation)
objects.description: Actor may sell session tokens, credentials, or foothold access on criminal markets or via access brokers. Buyers may use access for ransomware, fraud, or further espionage. This increases the potential for secondary impacts and attribution complexity.

objects.name: MSP-IMPACT (business/operational outcome)
objects.description: Potential outcomes include operational disruption, data theft, reputational damage, regulatory reporting and remediation costs. In this ACSC case immediate containment limited impact; represent this as a possible outcome in your flow.

objects.name: MSP-MITIGATE (Defender / Response)
objects.description:
Contain & remediate (prioritised):

Terminate all active sessions for compromised accounts and revoke cached session tokens immediately (invalidate session tokens from AVD/tenant).

Reset credentials & re-enrol MFA for affected accounts; force password rotation for accounts in scope.

Block/isolated unmanaged devices: require MSP-managed device policy for privileged access; revoke access from personal devices until compliant.

Hunt & triage: run SIEM hunts for session_create events without preceding login_success, sessions from unmanaged device_ids and lateral movement originating from AVD session hosts. Preserve forensic logs and IOCs in a private store.

Communicate & share IOCs with ASD/ACSC and affected clients; engage IR and regulatory processes as required.

objects.name: Attacker Staging Server / Cloud Storage
objects.description: External server or cloud storage used to stage/exfiltrate data or store tokens for sale

objects.name: MSP-LONG-TERM-STEALTH (persistence)
objects.description: Actor chooses to remain stealthy, create low-noise persistence (stable service account, scheduled tasks, living-off-the-land tooling). Use this when monetisation is intended later or to avoid immediate detection. Dwell may extend into weeks/months if undetected.

objects.name: MSP-ALTERNATE-INITIAL-ACCESS
objects.description: When the gating condition MSP-PRECONDITION-CACHEDSESSION is FALSE (no recoverable cached AVD session artifacts on the personal device), adversaries frequently pivot to noisier but effective initial-access approaches: targeted phishing (spear-phishing to contractor/staff addresses), credential stuffing against MSP/tenant portals using breached credential lists, or social-engineering techniques to obtain MFA bypass tokens. These techniques are more likely to produce authentication logs and/or email / gateway telemetry but remain commonly used by access brokers aiming to gain a foothold when low-noise token reuse is unavailable.
